title: PGA Tour: Big shake-up at Frys.com Open
text:
PGA Tour: Big shake-up at Frys.com Open By Carl Steward Posted: 10/18/2015 03:10:52 PM PDT Updated: 10/18/2015 04:01:53 PM PDT NAPA â€” The Frys.com Open will have a new sponsor starting next year, as well as a five-year agreement to remain at Silverado Resort, ending long-held speculation that the tournament would return to the South Bay in the near future. 
It was announced Sunday on Golf Channel that grocery chain Safeway will be the new sponsor of the event, which has been under the Fry's Electronics banner since 2007. 
The tournament will now be called the Safeway Open and the PGA Tour confirmed its new deal to keep the event at Silverado through 2020. The Napa course was supposed to be a temporary host site until the event could return to Morgan Hill and be played at magnate John Fry's ultra-private course, The Institute. 
Complications in building a large, castle-replica clubhouse at The Institute ultimately derailed that plan, however. The tournament was played at nearby CordeValle Golf Club in San Martin from 2010 to 2013 with that goal in mind, but when delays persisted, the event was played at Silverado last year and this year. 
There was an option to return to the Napa course again in 2016 under the Frys.com sponsorship, but Fry's executive vice president Kathy Kolder said the company is "re-strategizing" its future in regards to professional golf. 
"As soon as our elaborate clubhouse is finally built, we hope to announce an even more spectacular event," said Kolder. Advertisement 
The tournament has made significant strides under the Frys.com sponsorship and raised more than $6 million for charity during its eight-year run. In 2012, the Frys.com became the leadoff event in the Tour's revamped wrap-around season starting in the fall. In recent years, the event has been able to attract some of the top names in golf, including Tiger Woods, Ernie Els and Rory McIlroy, who played the event this year. Woods was supposed to play this year but scratched due to back surgery. 
The PGA Tour subsequently issued a press release announcing the new arrangement. Said commissioner Tim Finchem in the statement, "We'd like to thank John Fry, Kathy Kolder and everyone at Fry's for their tremendous support of the event since it's inception. Thanks to their involvement, the event has become a pivotal stop in the season-long race for the FedEx Cup." 
Silverado has long wished to regain a permanent PGA Tour event, having hosted one from 1968 through 1980 under two different sponsors, Kaiser and Anheuser-Busch. The tournament moved to Virginia in 1981. PGA Champions Tour events (seniors) were staged at Silverado from 1989 to 2002. Follow Carl Steward on Twitter at twitter.com/stewardsfolly .
